elements.text: Hot off ze presses, another blog about trying programming languages, this time with some code and less high level details

text: Glad you found Rust so appealing. :+1:

elements.text: Glad you found Rust so appealing.

text: It's a really nice tool that compliments some gaps I have elsewhere.  It solves my hobby needs squarely. I'm greedy - I want it to also solve my professional needs, but maybe in 5 yrs or something.

elements.text: It's a really nice tool that compliments some gaps I have elsewhere.  It solves my hobby needs squarely. I'm greedy - I want it to also solve my professional needs, but maybe in 5 yrs or something.

text:
I've started deep diving into Rust ~2 months ago and I also absolutely love the language and tooling. Basically everything someone "should do If they know what they're doing" in C++ is baked right into the language with pretty intuitive Syntax. Also, no more CMake... No words needed I guess.

Out of interest:
What do you think about Rust's approach to placing unit tests? Initially I found it weird, but now I find myself trying to emulate that using CMake and doctest if I do have to use C++

elements.text:
I've started deep diving into Rust ~2 months ago and I also absolutely love the language and tooling. Basically everything someone "should do If they know what they're doing" in C++ is baked right into the language with pretty intuitive Syntax. Also, no more CMake... No words needed I guess.

Out of interest:
What do you think about Rust's approach to placing unit tests? Initially I found it weird, but now I find myself trying to emulate that using CMake and doctest if I do have to use C++

text: I've only written like 1 unit test so far. Mostly because I'm still in the hacking phase of a project. But they seem pretty sensible to me. What I find interesting is that they tend to benchmark code in unit tests. Which is usually where I benchmark in C++. Or do you mean doctests specifically?

elements.text: I've only written like 1 unit test so far. Mostly because I'm still in the hacking phase of a project. But they seem pretty sensible to me. What I find interesting is that they tend to benchmark code in unit tests. Which is usually where I benchmark in C++. Or do you mean doctests specifically?

text:
I also like how you can tag code with: `#[allow(dead_code)]`
so VSCode doesn't yell at you for not using every function in an API lol

elements.text: I also like how you can tag code with:
#[allow(dead_code)]
so VSCode doesn't yell at you for not using every function in an API lol

text: What I meant mostly was that you write your unit tests pretty much right next to the production code

elements.text: What I meant mostly was that you write your unit tests pretty much right next to the production code

text: Somehow that makes testing much harder to ignore longer than I should and less of a hassle

elements.text: Somehow that makes testing much harder to ignore longer than I should and less of a hassle

text: Yea I mean it does feel weird because pretty much every other languages considers them seperate entities. But take C++ via VisualStudio for example. You often need to make a separate project and bounce between your code and the test to see whats going on

elements.text: Yea I mean it does feel weird because pretty much every other languages considers them seperate entities. But take C++ via VisualStudio for example. You often need to make a separate project and bounce between your code and the test to see whats going on

text: yea I mean if a test fails how convenient is it to be pointed right to either the block that failed or the test which could be wrong :).

elements.text: yea I mean if a test fails how convenient is it to be pointed right to either the block that failed or the test which could be wrong :).

text: I also really like the doc tests idea. Like the "does this example still work?" Whether the author cares or not the readers gets the truth.

elements.text: I also really like the doc tests idea. Like the "does this example still work?" Whether the author cares or not the readers gets the truth.

text: I had my big "Aha" moment when I was confronted with a multi loc embedded C code base at work (Spoiler: not an Embedded Guy at all). Basically it was a horribly convoluted project structure to begin with. But having a mostly, but not fully consisted, duplicated and deeply nested hierarchy for the tests was miserable

elements.text: I had my big "Aha" moment when I was confronted with a multi loc embedded C code base at work (Spoiler: not an Embedded Guy at all). Basically it was a horribly convoluted project structure to begin with. But having a mostly, but not fully consisted, duplicated and deeply nested hierarchy for the tests was miserable

text: yea that sounds horrific but I can imagine that happening.

elements.text: yea that sounds horrific but I can imagine that happening.

text: My best estimate after half a year was that roughly 1/3 of the tests weren't even in sync with their code anymore (some even disabled a couple of years ago with macros)

elements.text: My best estimate after half a year was that roughly 1/3 of the tests weren't even in sync with their code anymore (some even disabled a couple of years ago with macros)

text: So far I've only worked at one place that used unit tests correctly. I'm not even a software engineer, I just have to write software or else people don't pay me lol

elements.text: So far I've only worked at one place that used unit tests correctly. I'm not even a software engineer, I just have to write software or else people don't pay me lol

text:
In defense of the people at work: they're great people, extremely friendly and helpful and excellent embedded guys. But none of them actually have a software background and basically the entire department spent the past decade mostly on firefighting mode.
But that just points out how important it is to make such things the path of least resistance to begin with

elements.text:

text: Yea making it easier to do things right, and harder to do things wrong, increases the likelihood that it will be done right. And yea it sounds like we kind of interface in a similar part of the world from different angles.

elements.text: Yea making it easier to do things right, and harder to do things wrong, increases the likelihood that it will be done right. And yea it sounds like we kind of interface in a similar part of the world from different angles.

text: Well that was a far too large detour for why I'm kinda intrigued by Rust's approach to unit tests, with only integration tests being a fully separate crate

elements.text: Well that was a far too large detour for why I'm kinda intrigued by Rust's approach to unit tests, with only integration tests being a fully separate crate

text: I'm still too new to even be worried about unit testing, hopefully in a week it'll be more of an issue. Right now I'm stringing together a bunch of math in an API and it's a strong "to be determined" as to what math I even want to use yet.

text: Oh at work it's a nightmare. I'm in yet another uphill battle for doing barebones things. I don't know if a lot of people here fully realize how hard it is to get people in industry to do sensible things. Like how much politics, people trying not to get in trouble, and hurt feelings has to occur.

text: My advice is - throw yourself into some of those projects and learn something new :slightly_smiling_face:. I do a fair bit of stats and machine learning for a living and by education. So that's less interesting for me. I'm mostly interested in computer science stuff in general(not my biggest strength for sure), but also the kinds of tools and systems people are inventing here. Lots of inspiration to be found.

text:
Do you guys know of some package or something to write inline tests in Julia like with  C++ doctests or Rust. I really miss that feature in Julia. In python I write doctests and examples in the docstrings way past the point where inlining is sensible just to not have to deal with external testing structures. In Julia I just went with the prescribed test folder route, but miss my next-to-the-code tests so much. 

I'd never thought I'd miss Python or C++'s testing.

elements.text:
Do you guys know of some package or something to write inline tests in Julia like with  C++ doctests or Rust. I really miss that feature in Julia. In python I write doctests and examples in the docstrings way past the point where inlining is sensible just to not have to deal with external testing structures. In Julia I just went with the prescribed test folder route, but miss my next-to-the-code tests so much. 

I'd never thought I'd miss Python or C++'s testing.

text: Shouldn't inline testing work with Pytest as well? I've only ever done small experiments with that, but I was of the impression that you can make it work

elements.text: Shouldn't inline testing work with Pytest as well? I've only ever done small experiments with that, but I was of the impression that you can make it work

text: Though that probably kills tox, which would suck

text:
Just by thinking about this again I searched and stumbled across <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/defining-tests-next-to-functions/32155|https://discourse.julialang.org/t/defining-tests-next-to-functions/32155>

Love the conversation about Excel+VBA+code generation, I can really relate to that. Most of my work involves porting a big Excel formula generator monster into something more maintanable and extendable. Luckily I've got lots is say in this, so we are building from scratch and mostly in Julia!

attachments.title: Defining tests next to functions
attachments.text: For languages without classes tests are in my opinion a great way to document functions. For example, when I have the function function str2int(letter::String) letter = uppercase(letter) @assert occursin(r"[A-Z]+", letter) ch = letter[1] i = Int(ch) - 64 end then the goal is immediately clear when I read @test str2int("C") == 3 Unfortunately, all languages I know of tend to put these test in a file far away from the definition of the actual function. When we define these tests right bel...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Defining tests next to functions
